title: 114_s1989
content: The "Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015" allows for direct primary care service arrangements where individuals pay a fixed fee for ongoing primary care services, not billed to third parties. This arrangement is not considered a health plan or insurance for tax purposes. The Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015 allows for direct primary care service arrangements with fixed fees for ongoing services. The act also includes a provision for periodic provider fees to be treated as medical care. The Medicare Primary Care Medical Home Demonstration Program is also introduced. The Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015 introduces a Primary Care Medical Home Model under Section 1115A of the Social Security Act. This model allows qualified direct primary care medical home practices to receive periodic fees for providing services to individuals enrolled under part B of title XVIII. The Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015 establishes a model where qualified direct primary care medical home practices can receive periodic fees for providing services to individuals enrolled under part B of title XVIII. The Secretary will determine the periodic fee to be paid to these practices participating in the model. The Secretary will establish a periodic fee for qualified direct primary care medical home practices participating in the model under the Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015. The fee cannot exceed twenty percent of the estimated monthly amount payable from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for services. The Secretary will establish a periodic fee for qualified direct primary care medical home practices participating in the model under the Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015, not exceeding twenty percent of the estimated monthly amount payable from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for services. The fee will be adjusted based on a performance benchmark using ACO quality measures in the Medicare shared savings program. The Secretary will establish a performance benchmark for direct primary care medical home practices participating in the model under the Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015. The periodic fee paid to practices meeting or exceeding the benchmark shall be adjusted in the second year of the model. The Secretary will adjust the periodic fee paid to direct primary care medical home practices based on their performance benchmark. If the benchmark is met or exceeded, the fee will increase by 5 percent, and if not met, it will decrease by 5 percent. If the benchmark is not met for two consecutive years, the Secretary will terminate the practice from the model. The periodic fee paid to direct primary care medical home practices will be reduced by 5 percent for each enrolled individual under clause (i). The participation of a practice will be terminated if the performance benchmark is not met for 2 consecutive years. Qualified practices must provide preventive care and wellness counseling. Each qualified direct primary care medical home practice must offer preventive care, wellness counseling, primary care, coordination with specialty and hospital care, 7-day per week appointments, secure e-mail and telephone consultation, and a primary care provider panel size that supports provider ability. The Secretary shall prioritize direct primary care practices enrolling dual eligible individuals. The Secretary prioritizes direct primary care practices enrolling dual eligible individuals, who are individuals enrolled in part B of title XVIII and meet specific criteria under the Social Security Act. Care provided in these practices is not considered insurance. The Social Security Act prioritizes direct primary care practices enrolling dual eligible individuals. Care provided in these practices is not considered insurance and is not subject to regulation as an insurance product by State insurance commissioners. Practices participating in the model must submit an annual report on the progress of individuals with chronic conditions. Direct primary care practices participating in the model must submit an annual report to the Secretary on the progress of individuals with chronic conditions, including metrics such as emergency room visits, hospitalizations, surgeries, specialist visits, and advanced radiology use. The Secretary will provide qualified direct primary care medical home practices with necessary patient data for clinical purposes and evaluation of the model. Physicians or practitioners currently opted out of Medicare can still participate in the model. Physicians or practitioners currently opted out of Medicare can participate in a qualified direct primary care medical home practice under this model. Payment can be made for services provided to Medicare beneficiaries with whom they have a private contract. Excluded physicians or practitioners from Federal health care programs are not eligible. The model allows physicians or practitioners opted out of Medicare to participate in a direct primary care practice. Excluded providers from Federal health care programs are not eligible. The model will run for at least 3 years, with potential expansion after the third year. The Secretary will conduct the model for a minimum of 3 years. After the third year, qualified direct primary care medical home practices meeting specific requirements can continue permanently. After 3 years, qualified direct primary care medical home practices meeting specific requirements can continue permanently and expand nationwide if the majority meet the criteria. SEC. 5. USE OF DIRECT PRIMARY CARE MEDICAL HOMES UNDER THE MEDICARE ADVANTAGE PROGRAM. The Medicare Advantage program allows organizations to contract with qualified direct primary care medical home practices to offer primary care services and share savings. Qualified direct primary care medical home practices are defined as those described in the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.
